expectations:
- It's fine (and expected) to mention popular frameworks like Scrum and Kanban as part of the methodologies
      - MUST be in Brazilian Portuguese

      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Don't use vendors in chapter titles or descriptions (e.g. "npm", "yarn", "Redux", etc.)
    - Except are for widely known tools related to the course (e.g. "Git" in a programming course)
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Model C provides the most comprehensive and well-structured curriculum with 79 chapters covering an exceptional breadth of topics. It excels in several areas: (1) Strong theoretical foundations including complexity theory, Cynefin, systems thinking, and Little's Law as dedicated chapters; (2) Excellent separation of concerns - Scrum is broken into multiple focused chapters (planning, daily, review, retrospective, artefatos, DoD), same for Kanban (fundamentals, boards/policies, WIP/flow, metrics, demand management); (3) Covers advanced/niche topics others miss: IA/ML in agile, hardware/IoT/embedded, SRE and reliability, security/privacy, data/analytics agility, financial/budgeting, contracts, governance/compliance, regulated sectors; (4) Proper scaling coverage with dedicated chapters for SAFe, LeSS, Nexus, and Scrum@Scale separately; (5) Good career chapter at the end; (6) Titles are concise and descriptions follow the no-fluff guidelines well; (7) All in Brazilian Portuguese as required. The granularity is appropriate - not too verbose in titles, and descriptions are direct. Minor weakness: some chapters could arguably be combined, and a few descriptions use slightly longer phrasing than necessary, but overall this is the most thorough and well-organized curriculum.

Model F is extremely comprehensive with 61 chapters and demonstrates deep expertise. Strengths: (1) Excellent theoretical grounding with systems thinking, complexity, and Cynefin early on; (2) Strong product-oriented perspective with discovery, experimentation, validation as separate chapters; (3) Good coverage of often-overlooked topics: compliance/audit, work not planned, knowledge management, maturity assessment, supplier management, ITSM integration; (4) Proper separation of Scrum into multiple chapters (PO in depth, SM in depth, events in practice); (5) Metrics well separated into product, engineering/delivery, and flow categories; (6) Financial management, contracts, and governance well covered; (7) Concise titles and direct descriptions; (8) All in Brazilian Portuguese. Weaknesses: Some chapters feel slightly overlapping (e.g., 'Priorização e tomada de decisão' and 'Gestão de backlog' have some overlap), and the ordering sometimes jumps between topics. Missing dedicated chapters for some scaling frameworks individually (SAFe, LeSS, Nexus are combined). Still, this is an excellent and very thorough curriculum.

Model G provides 51 chapters with strong technical depth and good breadth. Strengths: (1) Excellent technical coverage including DDD/event storming, architecture, chaos engineering, feature flags/canary releases, which many others miss; (2) Good theoretical foundations with Cynefin and complexity; (3) Strong product management and UX coverage; (4) Good separation of metrics (flow, product, business); (5) Covers contracts, regulated sectors, governance; (6) Includes communities of practice, maturity assessment, and talent management; (7) Concise titles mostly following guidelines; (8) In Brazilian Portuguese. Weaknesses: (1) Some chapters lean heavily technical (DDD, chaos engineering, microsserviços) which may be beyond the scope of an Agile Methodologies course - these are more software engineering topics; (2) Scrum is somewhat compressed compared to its importance; (3) Some titles could be more concise (e.g., 'Comunicação, negociação e resolução de conflitos'); (4) The curriculum feels slightly more like a software engineering curriculum with agile overlays rather than a pure agile methodologies course.

Model A provides 48 well-organized chapters with good coverage. Strengths: (1) Excellent Scrum coverage broken into 6 detailed chapters; (2) Good Kanban coverage with 4 dedicated chapters including cadências; (3) Covers important topics like Management 3.0, Design Thinking, Lean Startup, Product Discovery; (4) Good scaling coverage with SAFe, LeSS, Nexus, and Spotify as separate chapters; (5) Includes ethics, remote work, certifications, and career chapters; (6) Concise titles and descriptions following guidelines well; (7) All in Brazilian Portuguese; (8) Good logical progression. Weaknesses: (1) Missing some advanced topics like security/DevSecOps, architecture, SRE, compliance/governance, contracts, financial/budgeting; (2) Less coverage of testing strategies beyond TDD/BDD; (3) No dedicated chapter on complexity theory/Cynefin; (4) Missing portfolio management; (5) Tools chapter names vendors implicitly. Still a strong curriculum but not as comprehensive as the top models.

Model E provides 47 chapters with solid overall coverage. Strengths: (1) Good breadth covering Scrum in detail (4+ chapters including separate PO, SM, team chapters); (2) Includes important topics like contracts, budgeting, business agility, HR, portfolio management; (3) Good coverage of technical practices, CI/CD, DevOps, quality; (4) Includes complexity/Cynefin, AI, certifications, career; (5) Studies of case chapter for practical application; (6) All in Brazilian Portuguese. Weaknesses: (1) Some titles are verbose (e.g., 'SAFe – Scaled Agile Framework', 'LeSS – Large-Scale Scrum', 'Outros Frameworks de Escala'); (2) 'Estudos de Caso e Anti-Padrões' as a chapter feels like it could be a project/assessment which the prompt says to avoid; (3) Kanban only gets one chapter which is insufficient for mastery; (4) Some descriptions use slightly flowery language; (5) Missing some topics like SRE, security/DevSecOps, data/analytics, hardware agile. Overall solid but less refined than the top models.

Model B provides only 30 chapters, making it the least comprehensive curriculum. Strengths: (1) Clean structure and logical progression; (2) Covers core topics: Scrum, Kanban, XP, Lean, scaling, leadership, business agility; (3) Includes contracts chapter which is often missed; (4) Concise titles; (5) All in Brazilian Portuguese; (6) Includes career and certifications. Weaknesses: (1) Significantly fewer chapters than competitors - 30 is insufficient for mastery-level coverage; (2) Scrum compressed into just 4 chapters (Fundamentos, Papéis, Eventos, Artefatos) - not enough depth; (3) Missing many important topics: security, architecture, compliance/governance, portfolio management, financial/budgeting, complexity theory, Design Thinking, product discovery, remote/distributed teams, anti-patterns, ethics, AI/automation, testing strategies; (4) No dedicated chapter on facilitation; (5) Some critical areas like metrics only get one chapter; (6) 'Value Stream Management' description uses filler-ish language ('acelerar o tempo de chegada ao mercado'). This curriculum would not prepare someone to be at the top of the field due to significant gaps.

Model D provides only 26 chapters, the second least comprehensive. Strengths: (1) Clean structure; (2) Covers core frameworks (Scrum, Kanban, XP, Lean); (3) Includes OKRs, coaching, facilitation, DevOps; (4) Concise titles; (5) In Brazilian Portuguese; (6) Career chapter included. Weaknesses: (1) Only 26 chapters is far too few for comprehensive mastery coverage; (2) Many critical topics are completely missing: security, architecture, contracts, financial/budgeting, portfolio management beyond one brief mention, complexity theory, product discovery, Design Thinking, remote/distributed work, ethics, AI, testing strategies, anti-patterns, organizational design models; (3) Scrum compressed into only 3 chapters; (4) Scaling gets just one chapter for all frameworks combined; (5) Quality/engineering topics get insufficient depth; (6) Some titles use redundant patterns (e.g., 'Agilidade Estratégica com OKRs' - 'com OKRs' is somewhat verbose); (7) Missing dedicated metrics chapters for product vs flow. This curriculum has the most significant gaps and would not adequately prepare someone for advanced roles.

Model C provides an incredibly extensive and thorough curriculum (76 chapters) that perfectly aligns with the 'top 1%' requirement. It not only covers the standard agile frameworks and scaling methods but dives deep into advanced and modern topics like Agile for Data/Analytics, Agile for AI/Machine Learning, Hardware/IoT, Site Reliability Engineering (SRE), Systems Thinking, and Theory of Constraints. The titles and descriptions are completely devoid of fluff and get straight to the point. It perfectly meets all prompt requirements.

Model F is also exceptional, offering a highly comprehensive 60-chapter curriculum. It stands out by including deep dives into Team Topologies, Monte Carlo forecasting, DORA metrics, DevOps/SRE, and how to handle unplanned work and ITIL/ITSM in an agile context. It is very close to Model C in quality and depth, lacking only a few niche modern applications (like AI/Data) that Model C included. No fluff, completely vendor-neutral, and highly professional.

Model G is fantastic and offers a very mature curriculum (51 chapters) with a strong emphasis on modern software engineering practices intersecting with agile, such as Domain-Driven Design (DDD), Chaos Engineering, and architectural resilience. It strictly adheres to all formatting and content constraints, providing concise descriptions and a dedicated career chapter.

Model A provides a very solid and comprehensive 49-chapter curriculum. It covers all the essential frameworks, scaling methods, and business agility concepts well. While it is excellent, it slightly lacks the cutting-edge depth in product engineering and cross-disciplinary agile applications (like Data or Hardware) seen in the higher-ranked models. It follows all rules regarding fluff and vendor neutrality perfectly.

Model E offers a very comprehensive 47-chapter course. It correctly covers history, frameworks, scaling, engineering practices, and career development. It is highly comparable to Model A, though slightly less granular in some advanced metrics and systems thinking areas. It perfectly follows the formatting and tone guidelines.

Model B is structurally sound and follows all instructions regarding formatting, language, and avoiding fluff. However, with only 30 chapters, it does not reach the granular depth required to take a student to the 'top 1%' or prepare them for a Master's/PhD level of expertise compared to the leading models. It covers the basics and some advanced topics but misses the extensive practical and edge-case applications.

Model D provides the shortest curriculum (26 chapters). While it adheres to the formatting rules and tone constraints, it completely fails the primary objective of creating an exhaustive, extensive, and comprehensive curriculum that prepares a learner to be in the 'top 1%'. It acts more as a standard overview of agile rather than a masterclass.

Mais completo e com progressão clara do básico ao avançado. Cobre fundamentos (manifesto, empirismo, complexidade), métodos (Scrum/Kanban/XP), engenharia moderna (CI/CD, SRE, DevSecOps), métricas (produto e entrega), discovery/experimentos, escala, governança/compliance, setores regulados, trabalho distribuído, ética e carreira. Linguagem consistente em pt-BR e descrições objetivas, com pouco “fluff”.

Cobertura ampla e moderna, muito alinhada a prática real: sistemas/filas/TOC, produto e discovery, Scrum/Kanban/híbridos, engenharia (trunk-based, SRE/DevSecOps), métricas (DORA e produto), finanças/fornecedores/compliance, maturidade e carreira. Boa progressão e concisão. Pequenos pontos: alguns termos em inglês sem necessidade (“rolling wave”, “North Star”) e algumas descrições um pouco densas.

Currículo muito forte e abrangente, com bons tópicos avançados (DDD/event storming, chaos engineering, LPM/governança financeira, reporting executivo, maturidade, toolchain vendor-neutral). Inclui carreira e tendências. Penaliza levemente por alguns títulos/descrições mais longos e por ficar um pouco mais “engenharia/software” do que “metodologias ágeis” em geral, embora ainda relevante.

Bem completo e atualizado, cobrindo Scrum/Kanban/XP/Lean, discovery/produto/UX, métricas, DevOps, escala, transformação, contratos, finanças, IA, estudos de caso, tendências e carreira. Contudo, há violações de “vendor neutral” ao citar ferramentas/frameworks específicos em tendências e facilitação (por exemplo, Modern Agile, Heart of Agile, Unfix, Liberating Structures) e algumas descrições um pouco mais verbosas.

Amplo e bem estruturado, com boa profundidade em Scrum/Kanban e tópicos úteis (discovery, métricas, DevOps, escala, coaching, mudança, setores não tecnológicos, tendências, carreira). Problemas: várias menções não-vendor-neutral/questionáveis (Spotify Model como capítulo dedicado; “BOSSA nova”), alguns anglicismos e pequenos erros/ruídos (“práticas coroárias”). Menos cobertura de governança/compliance e finanças do que os melhores.

Cobre o essencial (manifesto, Scrum, Kanban, Lean, XP, priorização/estimativas, escala, OKRs, coaching, DevOps, transformação, governança e carreira) com concisão. Mas é pouco extenso para a ambição do prompt: faltam profundidade em discovery/experimentos, métricas modernas de entrega/produto, compliance/setores regulados, contratos/finanças, SRE/segurança, tendências e nuances de seleção por contexto.

Boa base para iniciante e intermediário (Scrum/Kanban/XP, métricas, produto, escala, mudança, contratos, certificações e carreira). Porém, cobertura é limitada para “mastery”: quase nada de discovery avançado/experimentação, governança/compliance, finanças/portfólio, segurança, confiabilidade/ops, trabalho remoto, anti-patterns mais amplos e tendências atuais. Menos capítulos e menor profundidade geral.
